items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
Water levels are remaining high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water. 
Further rainfall is forecast throughout Tuesday (27/12/2022) afternoon and early evening and again on Wednesday (28/12/2022). No property flooding is expected, and we do not expect to issue a Flood Warning at this time.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 11:59 AM on 28/12/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mersey Estuary at Warrington
items.message:

Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.

The Environment Agency Flood Warning System has issued this message based on rising river or tidal levels.
We are temporarily automating our messages due to industrial action.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.63mAOD at 17:30 on 27/12/22.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 130 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next 2 days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 20:00 on 27/12/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Wey
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but steady on the River Wey as a result of previous heavy rainfall. Further light rainfall is forecast over this afternoon. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this afternoon, 27/12/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Soar in Leicestershire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: Mid Bristol Avon area

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message: River levels remain high at the Bradford on Avon river gauge because of the rainfall over the past few days but are beginning to fall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed. Further rainfall is expected in the evening of Tuesday 27/12/ 2022 and on Wednesday 28/12/2022. River levels are expected to rise again because of this rainfall. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded. Refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 14:00 on Tuesday, 27/12/22, or as the situation changes.

items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed.  River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.   We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message: Water levels remain high at the Sherborne Lake river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, there is a low risk of flooding to low-lying land and roads today, Tuesday, 27/11/22. Locations most vulnerable to flooding are the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole. Further showery rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high over the next 24 hours. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers which may be flooded. Please refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 17:00 on Tuesday, 27/11/22, or as the situation changes

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely to continue today, Tuesday 27th December, and overnight into Wednesday 28th December. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Wednesday 28th December.

items.description: River Lugg south of Leominster
items.message: River levels remain high at the Lugwardine river gauge following recent heavy rainfall. Flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop. We expect river levels to remain elevated for the next few days and potentially impacted by additional rainfall forecast for later today, 27/12/22, and tomorrow, 28/12/22. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated by midday on 28/12/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames at Trowlock Island
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: Upper Bristol Avon area
items.message: River levels remain high at the Great Somerford river gauge because of the rainfall over the past few days but are beginning to fall. Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing. We expect flooding to affect the road at Reybridge. Further rainfall is expected in the evening of Tuesday 27/12/2022 and on Wednesday 28/12/2022. River levels are expected to rise again because of this rainfall. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded. Refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 14:00 on Tuesday, 27/12/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message: The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.027 m and is falling by approximately 13 mm per hour. The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.25 m and is falling by approximately 6.5 mm per hour. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m, the road from Muchelney to Long load if this level exceeds 7.86 and the road from Muchelney to Thorney if this level exceeds 7.93 m. Property flooding is possible if this level exceeds 8.35 m. Unsettled weather is forecast for the next 48hrs. The River Yeo at Muchelney is forecast to remain stable as a result.

items.description: Lower River Loddon
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: Lower Tone and Parrett Moors
items.message: The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.36 m and is falling by 7.5 mm per hour. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45 m. The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 5.51 m and is falling by approximately 5 mm per hour. There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if this level reaches 8.30 m. Unsettled weather is forecast for the next 48 hours. The River Tone at Currymoor is forecast to rise as a result.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high but gradualy falling on the Lower Cherwell as a result of recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue today, 27/12/2022, especially in the areas around Thrupp. 
This morning, 27/12/2022, should be mainly dry, with further rainfall forecast this afternoon and overnight. We expect river levels to continue to slowly fall over the next few days but will remain sensitive to further rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated this evening, 27/12/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Frome and Cam
items.message: River levels remain high but steady at the Brimscombe river gauge as a result of recent rainfall, consequently flooding of roads and farmland may continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Elmore to Sharpness. Other locations that may be affected include Chalford, Leonard Stanley and Cambridge. We expect river levels to remain elevated for the next few days and potentially impacted by additional rainfall forecast for later today, 27/12/22, and tomorrow, 28/12/22. This message will be updated by 12:00pm on 28/12/22 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames and tributaries in the Oxford area
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have risen on the River Thames as a result of recent rainfall. This alert has been issued due to elevated river levels around Sandford. This message will not be updated, but river levels may rise further and come out of banks. Please take care when walking along the Thames Path and check River Levels online for current levels at Kings Lock, Godstow Lock, Osney Lock, Iffly Lock, Minns Estate and Cold Harbour.
 
We are temporarily automating our messages due to industrial action.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely this afternoon, Tuesday 27th December and overnight in to Wednesday 28th December. Water levels are expected to continue to rise gradually over the next few hours in response to forecast rainfall, together with the natural tide locking effect on the Broads. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Wednesday 28th December.
